section.text: Yes. Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Gruber", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "4f8deb4f-f558-4aaa-8b92-084be4722f08", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup Inc."}

section.text: Good morning, Scott.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "919b10b7-d085-4813-a3fd-89e89127259d", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Good morning, Scott.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "a5a285ac-e76a-4e44-9da2-8853b70c6628", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: So your margins are basically now where you thought they'd be in 4Q, and I understand there's some puts and takes on 4Q. I'm trying to get a sense for where we stand on multiple fronts. So some additional color on where you stand on resetting the price book, where you stand on seeing improvement in delivery costs and delivery timing, and what you're seeing in terms of stability on input cost inflation. So just some color, I know these are kind of key areas you guys have been focused on over the past year. So some additional color on these margin influences would be great.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Gruber", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "2f64efd0-4b2c-44e4-9340-6adcc37511ea", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup Inc."}

section.text: Yeah, Scott. It's a good question and it's a lot of things intention here. So over the past couple of years, we've been taking costs out of our organization, and we've been focused on pushing prices up. We had the most success in our quick-turn businesses that are associated with rising drilling activity in North America. And so, that's gone in the right direction.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "b6f03dd5-b951-473b-ae1c-d090ffd9deae", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: But on the other hand, as we've talked about on prior calls and in our prepared remarks, still face a lot of supply chain issues. So kind of a quick update on where we are on that. Broadly, things are getting better. However, I do want to say we're a long way from being normalized. And in certain categories, we're seeing things get a little bit worse. And so things like electric motors, actuators, PLCs, a lot of electrical components. Some of those got more expensive and more difficult through the quarter. Certain castings, in particular, coming out of Europe. I think there's something like 15 steel mills in Europe that have [Technical Issues] energy situation there, putting a little pressure on some of our businesses there are the counterexamples.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "b6f03dd5-b951-473b-ae1c-d090ffd9deae", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: But items like freight, freight is probably down 60% off the peak, which is good, going in the right direction, but still double where it was in 2020 and triple where it was in 2019. And as well, we're seeing deliveries of certain items push out. And so it was sort of broad normalization underway, and ports are slowly clearing. We're still way off the mark in terms of delivery reliabilities. Costs are still elevated. We face workforce challenges as do our vendors, particularly across North America.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "b6f03dd5-b951-473b-ae1c-d090ffd9deae", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: One of the developing items that we saw through the third quarter, some of our third-party machine shops now are running into labor shortages and machinist shortages. And so, on-time delivery slipped quite a bit in Q3. So it's -- those are the factors that are offsetting some of the price increases that we've been able to get and some of the costs that we've taken out. So I think, puts and takes in both directions around the margins.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "b6f03dd5-b951-473b-ae1c-d090ffd9deae", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Got you. Appreciate all the color there. And just shifting to capital return. It's a hot topic in oil services at this juncture. And we've heard several peers who've actually put forth capital return commitments. In thinking about NOV, I know you guys still have a long way here to see kind of full margin recovery, but assuming that plays out, how do you think about a capital return commitment and whether that makes sense for NOV?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Gruber", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "3033c8a9-cd59-46ad-ac61-3070b6d31fd7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup Inc."}

section.text: Yes. Hey, Scott, it's Jose. I'll tackle this one. Yeah, it's a good question. And certainly, sort of getting back to more normalized margins is something that we're very focused on and also just managing the tremendous amount of growth that we're currently experiencing in our business, which is a good news-bad news story, with the good news more outweighing the bad news, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "4d285384-348a-4d56-b4d7-ae3afbcbf487", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: When you're drawn 10% -- roughly 10% a quarter and 40-plus percent year-over-year, provided that you weren't mismanaging your working capital prior to that, it's going to consume some working capital and use some cash flow, right? And that's sort of where we are as a later-cycled business. But we'd much rather sacrifice a little free cash flow today to have a lot more down the road.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "4d285384-348a-4d56-b4d7-ae3afbcbf487", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: So I think we've been pretty clear about the historical cash flow generation capability of this business, which we expect to be even stronger going forward. We've never shied away from returning capital to our shareholders, having returned almost $5 billion of capital since 2014. And we've also been pretty clear about where we need to see our leverage metrics get, which is back to the 2 times or better gross debt-to-EBITDA metric.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "4d285384-348a-4d56-b4d7-ae3afbcbf487", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: So we're looking forward to arriving at the right place and time to where we can step up or return the capital again and things are certainly all heading in the right direction. So things look promising from that standpoint.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "4d285384-348a-4d56-b4d7-ae3afbcbf487", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Yeah. Appreciate that. We have to remind people that working capital is a high-class problem when it builds quickly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Gruber", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "1c6093a1-8a81-4504-974a-f7da8432ebc5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup Inc."}

section.text: Exactly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "1904f825-df2f-44e6-af19-eabca977cb2d", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: So we'll continue to stay updated. Thanks. Appreciate it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Gruber", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "139bd432-0fd1-4cc0-93ae-b2f9c01b68ea", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup Inc."}

section.text: You bet. Thanks, Scott.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "f445c537-c3e9-45c1-83bc-dec677d64956", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Thanks, Scott.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "509f3de3-6d30-4828-89b0-d5cd7b2d5cee", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Hey. Thanks. You guys talked about an expectation for improving orders. I'm just curious, it seemed like it's likely that you're going to stay above the 1 times book-to-bill here in CAPS as we move forward. When do you think Rig Tech could get back above 1 times?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Marc Bianchi", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "cc5e1b0c-1edf-4c76-b97f-768fe219ea5f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen Inc."}

section.text: Yeah. Marc, I think -- I actually think Q3 is just a temporary blip and I appreciate the question because if you focus in on our rig order book for the third quarter, what really changed from the second quarter was the absence of a wind turbine installation vessel. If you go back to the past several quarters, we pretty much had a wind turbine installation vessel large order every quarter. And so, we're engaged on building out, I think, 11 wind turbine installation vessels as a result of that growing backlog in that space. And what happened in the third quarter is we just didn't get any. So it just -- it fell off.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "1889909e-c26f-4b75-9f47-0c0ff06a5a40", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: If you look at our sort of more traditional oilfield order book in the third quarter, it actually -- for capital equipment, which is really the only piece of it that we report, it was up for both offshore and land customers. I think Jose mentioned in his prepared remarks, we got an order for a high-spec rig from a North American operator. And so, that helped double land rig orders sequentially and triple land rig orders year-over-year. And then offshore continued to move up as well. We went up about 15% sequentially.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "1889909e-c26f-4b75-9f47-0c0ff06a5a40", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: The point I was trying to make in my prepared remarks, though, is that even at rising levels moving up sequentially up into the right, still far less than the industry needs in order to sort of launch the major industrial effort that's required to get back to growing oil and gas production around the globe. And so, we think this is growing the right way. As we -- as I explained at length in my prepared remarks, the dynamics around demand for what we sell, I think, are very strong, very constructive over the next several quarters and really the next several years. And so, we're excited about that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "1889909e-c26f-4b75-9f47-0c0ff06a5a40", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And then, to kind of round out the picture. Rig Technology capital equipment is only one of really three big ways that drilling contractors spend money with NOV. And the other two are spare parts to support their rigs as [Technical Issues] And what we've seen, as Jose said in his prepared remarks, is sort of steadily rising demand for spare parts to support rig reactivations, rig operations. They're kind of flattish sequentially, but year-over-year, up 27% and up for both offshore and land. And then drill pipe is the third way that drilling contractors spend money with us. And that's actually in our Wellbore Technologies segment. And again, both of those just a monster order in Q2, down a bit in Q3 [Technical Issues] but still very, very strong. And in fact, Q3 was up 67% year-over-year. So you add all that together, we are seeing rising [Technical Issues] expectation that continues as the offshore gets back to work as drilling picks up in international markets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "1889909e-c26f-4b75-9f47-0c0ff06a5a40", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Yes. Okay. Super, Clay. Thanks for that. Jose, I don't think I heard anything unallocated. You usually don't guide to it, but it was up quite a bit from second quarter. How should we be thinking about that for fourth quarter?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Marc Bianchi", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "bd481c6f-a279-4380-8e5e-6ec7884a3435", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen Inc."}

section.text: Yeah. So from basically the elims line, moving as it normally does, a similar percentage from pre-elimination revenue and then probably looking at a couple of million dollar increase from -- at the EBITDA level with the growth.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "03158985-bf28-4739-9d5a-b7e59f4a1bb9", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Got it. So something like $60 million. Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Marc Bianchi", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "93b692a5-371c-4d59-8ca6-f91d6c4f5874", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen Inc."}

section.text: Yeah. Maybe just shy of that. Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "2054ebb3-bbfb-422a-a0fc-cacaeabb3156", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: I'll turn it back.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Marc Bianchi", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "01eefae8-ec6a-4b4a-993e-1dd892ca61d3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen Inc."}

section.text: Great. Thank you, Marc.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "eafc63a3-7377-4ba4-91a6-c507830c1f16", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Curran", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "88419373-a68b-4a73-8ed9-a9c086daf131", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global Holdings LLC"}

section.text: Hi, Tom.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "fab1c6ee-8012-4020-9c6d-94952dec1d0a", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Hi, Tom.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "8f379c72-7a71-420e-ac91-7b297d1df196", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: What would lead time be as the cap's divisions-wise unit quoting at this point for new build frac spreads? And when it comes to capital equipment sales for shale completions, what level of competition are you confronting from the secondary markets, such as auctions? How does the amount and pricing of used equipment out there compare to what you've seen at this point in prior U.S. up-cycles?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Curran", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "0acf9cec-6917-4d0c-ac8f-a881f1ae3059", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global Holdings LLC"}

section.text: I'll answer the second part of that question first. There's very little used equipment that's really can be refurbished economically. And what we've seen over the past year is more and more pressure pumpers in North America are pivoting towards buying new and the longevity and sort of the overall value offered by going to new versus used, I think, is a lot stronger.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "0de4cce4-cdba-4d5d-9144-919f3387c22b", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And then the first part of your question, I think, was lead times and more -- I'd say, plus/minus a year, tier four engines are eight months plus in terms of deliveries is what we're looking. And I will say, we made some true purchases of some of the key items, and so can probably deliver maybe, depending on what our customers are buying, maybe a little more quickly than our competitors out there. But on the whole, that's probably what you're looking at.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "0de4cce4-cdba-4d5d-9144-919f3387c22b", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Yeah. That's all consistent with the checks I've done, but I wanted to be sure I had you guys weigh in as well. Thanks for that, Clay.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Curran", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "26e4ff9e-66e8-4f9b-9fcd-e78ca18c6bd8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global Holdings LLC"}

section.text: Yeah.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "1a32c05b-00db-45a1-9f61-0e86858f95be", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And then, could you give us an update on your annual revenue expectations or even just potential for CCS and geothermal, respectively? By division, it seems as if Wellbore Technologies has a product suite that spans both of those new energy segments, while CAPS has some specific offerings for CCS. And then Rig Tech has done some custom designs and systems for geothermal. Maybe just an update on each of those renewables markets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Curran", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "bab55a93-8e73-4453-a1d5-f986549b5f00", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global Holdings LLC"}

section.text: Yeah. Tom, I think we'll hold back from providing the granularity that you're looking for. But our efforts related to energy transition opportunities are going very well. And particularly as Clay touched on the backlog and the ongoing work that we have related offshore wind construction vessels, momentum continues to build there as it does related to really a number of the other initiatives that we have going on related to energy transition, including geothermal that you're asking about.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "f3904a3e-3149-402a-8795-ebc79c7c21b1", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And really, we're seeing -- we saw a really rapid sequential growth going from Q2 to Q3. And I think the total company combined from a renewable standpoint was roughly $90 million or so in revenue in the third quarter at a really nice trajectory. So we're really pleased with the way that those initiatives are shaping up for the company.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "f3904a3e-3149-402a-8795-ebc79c7c21b1", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Yeah. And just to add just a touch more color. The wind installation vessel space where NOV is market leader, and we've come out with new technology that we referenced in our press release is the majority of that $90 million, but we're seeing really good growth in particular around geothermal offerings and I think we mentioned in our prepared remarks, ReedHycalog has emerged as a market leader in terms of hard rock drilling that's required for geothermal, but also generating a little bit of revenue in our solar initiative and a lot of interest in CCUS technologies.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "50799487-231d-417f-852c-ab24b1f350d1", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: We're the leading provider of gas processing, dehydration technologies that are directly applicable to CCUS. And so, we've got some FEED studies underway there. And so really across the board, very excited about all that. And then finally, to put a bar around it, in addition to fixed wind installation vessels, there's movement on the floating wind side as well. And there, as you move into deeper waters, it's kind of a different way that NOV can participate in those projects, with respect to helping build out the actual vessels, providing mooring systems and it's a larger kind of revenue opportunity for us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "50799487-231d-417f-852c-ab24b1f350d1", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And so, we're very pleased to be participating with partners and customers in Asia and the North Sea and looking at specific floating wind opportunities that could be real needle movers in the future. So we continue to prosecute these opportunities and excited about the future and believe we have a lot of value to bring to the energy transition.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "50799487-231d-417f-852c-ab24b1f350d1", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Thanks for all the color.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Curran", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "9b620e18-627a-4a7d-9269-8119be4682fa", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global Holdings LLC"}

section.text: You bet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "c65d1d86-77d8-4e77-ade8-eb5fbb94fb73", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Hey. Good morning. Thanks for taking my question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "eb73e50c-0308-433a-a9bd-ecedb9f2742d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning, David.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "f1f8611d-c974-42d7-b5b5-ce8f2c44bc53", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Calling in from Pickering Energy Partners. So I didn't think I would ask a question like this for a really long time, but here it goes. Given how much capacity Saudi is taken out of the jackup market, when I start to count the jackups that are going to be left, there just aren't that many that were delivered in the last 20 years that aren't already contracted, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "7f0439b6-e553-4e62-a184-40d9f0e6c4d8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: So assuming demand continues to grow for the next year or two, I think we can get to a point where the options to satisfy incremental demand becomes either a new jackup or the reactivation of a 40-some-year-old cold stacked rig that hasn't worked in several years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "7f0439b6-e553-4e62-a184-40d9f0e6c4d8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: Yeah.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "3f9bec45-6408-4422-be0d-ab30d5ae1a80", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: So my question is, in your view, do you think we'll see any new jackup orders in the next five years, but also, how should we think about the opportunity for NOV on reactivations of the much older assets? I expect those might include some pretty significant capital equipment upgrades.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "c5909804-6710-4894-8c1c-112a9bae7b34", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: Hey. Great, David. It's something.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "fc2e7967-1993-46d6-8c0a-b33f8b6d8a35", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: It is. It's an interesting comment for sure. And listen, you're probably aware, but in Saudi Arabia, there are plans to construct new jackups. And so, we just recently opened our joint venture with Aramco, built a rig equipment manufacturing facility there in the Kingdom, and that's to satisfy a very large land rig order. But in addition to that, the Saudis are moving forward with a program to build out 20 jackups over a period of time. And so, we're well positioned to participate in that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "a92b1d09-4845-44ab-96c9-bd8ccde9f012", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And so, that's one of the ways I think that the gap will be filled and that's sort of in addition to the, I think, 37 jackups that Aramco is adding in the offshore to grow their production. And so, yeah, we are, I think, starting to face constraints around rig availability, and that's the reason, frankly, that day rates have moved up so sharply. They've moved up materially for jackups, but in the floating space have roughly doubled in like a 12 to 18-month period. And so, all good. Industry is going back to work and very pleased that NOV is well positioned, I think, to help our offshore customers get there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "a92b1d09-4845-44ab-96c9-bd8ccde9f012", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Yeah, absolutely. I should have put an asterisk on that. Outside of ARO Drilling, if you think there's potential for new jackup orders in the next five years?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "22fa3bef-dd76-4965-821c-402d0090caed", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: Well, we're not forecasting at this point, to be clear, but the dynamics are certainly getting a lot closer to that supply-demand tipping point.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "0a9a285f-77c0-495c-9f20-b4395ce8d33f", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And switching to land. I have been wondering when we might see a new land rig ordered for the U.S., just given the remarkable increase in pricing. Would love to hear your outlook for additional new land rig orders in U.S., but international, if you have a few there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "cb200508-f9a9-4eaa-986b-c313850d7977", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: Sure.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "0d0fa2ae-e0c5-4225-9593-5bd75801f1a6", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And maybe any color you can give on what kind of conversations you're having?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Smith", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "8614900b-0b60-45de-adb4-affced965a8a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Pickering Energy Partners"}

section.text: Yeah. We follow that very closely. Just to put this in perspective, though, the day rate recoveries I just talked about in the offshore are really pretty recent. And in the land rig space in North America, for super-spec rigs, those probably front-ran the offshore by a quarter or two going in the right direction. We believe that we start to -- we're right at the edge kind of replacement economics. There's a lot of incremental day rate disclosure being made this week in earnings calls. But as we kind of move from the high $30,000 a day range up into the $40,000 a day range for super-spec rigs, I think it starts to become the investment opportunities there for new capacity start to look pretty compelling. And so, that's kind of where we are with respect to that category.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "29e4e0d3-d848-465b-a67b-900d4a15cfb6", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: In international markets, as I mentioned, we are in the process of building out a grand total of 50 rigs in our order for Saudi Arabia. We've delivered the first two, and the third is being commissioned right now. And so, we're just at the leading edge of that addition. And those are very capable high-specced rigs. But I think that's sort of an indicator of things to come. I think international markets, in particular, have a long ways to go in stepping up their technology that they apply in drilling -- in their drilling operations. And again, NOV is well positioned to help them accomplish that. So still ways away from kind of the new building of rigs that we saw in the prior super cycle, but certainly, all signs are encouraging that we're heading in the right direction.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "29e4e0d3-d848-465b-a67b-900d4a15cfb6", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: You bet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "7d9f4057-5206-4e82-abc6-bf916c32dd79", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Thanks, David.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "f308c51f-a175-4761-a658-8b0acd4779ca", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Thanks. Good morning, everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Gengaro", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "b48b1fc0-727e-4018-bbda-6b2aa0e75940", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel Financial Corp."}

section.text: Morning, Stephen.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "7226c4ff-c39e-4582-a0fb-ef474fed6dea", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Hey, Stephen.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "33fb31d3-9f3a-40ab-996b-6f733a0a1166", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Just curious, the third quarter, the Rig Tech margins were better than we thought. And based on the commentary you gave, they look to be increasing from here. How should we think about Rig Tech margins as we go into 2023?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Gengaro", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "0bb87a45-c6c0-4a8f-a34a-0c8f4dcfd5e1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel Financial Corp."}

section.text: Hey, Stephen, I think, look, obviously, it's dependent on kind of what [Technical Issues] and what the overall growth is. But I think we've repositioned the company appropriately. We've gotten the restructuring and cost-savings initiatives behind us at this point. So really, as we look at not just Rig Tech, but really all of the businesses. I think the best way to think about it is that we should start to see more of what those historical normalized incrementals have been. And so, for the rig business. Historically, that's been kind of a mid-20% type incrementals, CAPS, upper 20s, lower 30s, and wellbore, call it, somewhere between 30% and 40% incrementals.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "1ea0ea09-b33f-4e62-8866-68b15e3cce61", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: And so, I think we're approaching a place that, at least over a period of time, there's always ebbs and flows within a quarter, but over a reasonable period of time that we should be back to those normalized incrementals and hopefully all the charges and restructuring is completely behind us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "1ea0ea09-b33f-4e62-8866-68b15e3cce61", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Yes. Yeah, I mean normalized volumes, and then in addition, rig, rig really has been facing some headwinds related to supply chain issues as well. And so, kind of continued normalization of supply chain will help a lot. So those are good tailwinds for rig margins going forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "18c9698b-061b-4111-9a18-ecc08a57355c", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Okay. No, great. That's helpful color. And then the other quick one and I know it's a similar question looking out past the fourth quarter. But when you think of the CAPS business, I mean, it feels like momentum is building. It feels like you're on the cusp of sort of a pretty nice acceleration in the topline. Is that consistent with what you're seeing? And I mean do you think you could see a year or two of sort of outsized growth?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Gengaro", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "7a4ea409-2c4f-4c67-8e94-77feb1d99b76", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel Financial Corp."}

section.text: Great. No, thanks for all the detail on the call.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Gengaro", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "2586f8bb-d89c-4432-8f5a-6ea33f605352", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel Financial Corp."}

section.text: Thanks, Stephen.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Clay C. Williams", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "50002735-8d1b-48a8-a54a-77aee4d55d41", "speaker_title": "President, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Thank you, Stephen.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jose Bayardo", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "8e150636-13c1-4a97-a0e1-08c6511eddd2", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at NOV"}

section.text: Thank you, Michelle, and thank you, all, for joining us this morning. We look forward to discussing our fourth quarter and year-end results with you in February. Have a terrific day. Thank you.
